adolescent-and-emerging-adulthood/4.-cog.description:
Bibliography: Type: Journal Article Title: Beyond Simple Models of Self-Control to Circuit-Based Accounts of Adolescent Behavior, Author: Casey, B. J.; Journal: Annual Review of Psychology, Volume: 66, Issue: 1 Pages: 295-319 Year: 2015 DOI: 10.1146/annurev-psych-010814-015156 ISSN: 0066-4308, 1545-2085 Adolescence is the transition from childhood to adulthood that begins around the onset of puberty and ends with relative independence from the parent. This developmental period is one when an individual is probably stronger, of higher reasoning capacity, and more resistant to disease than ever before, yet when mortality rates increase by 200%. These untimely deaths are not due to disease but to preventable deaths associated with adolescents putting themselves in harm’s way (e.g., accidental fatalities). We present evidence that these alarming health statistics are in part due to diminished self-control—the ability to inhibit inappropriate desires, emotions, and actions in favor of appropriate ones. Findings of adolescent-speciﬁc changes in self-control and underlying brain circuitry are considered in terms of how evolutionarily based biological constraints and experiences shape the brain to adapt to the unique intellectual, physical, sexual, and social challenges of adolescence. Keywords: #Cognition #Development #Emotion #Motivation #Peers #Prefrontal-Cortex
The dual-system based largely on Metcalf & Mischel's (1999) two-system model of willpower. According to the model, self-control results from a balance between a 'cool' and a 'hot' system. The cool system is an emotionally neutral, strategic, and flexible cognitive system. The hot system is emotionally driven by fears, desires, and reflexes. The balance between these two system varies as a function of the individual, development, and stress. The dual-system model was used to heuristically explain brain systems underlying behavior involving immediate versus delayed rewards. Portions of the limbic system

adolescent-and-emerging-adulthood/5.-rac.title: @atkinQualitativeExaminationFamilial2022
adolescent-and-emerging-adulthood/5.-rac.description:
Bibliography: Type: Journal Article Title: A qualitative examination of familial racial-ethnic socialization experiences among multiracial American emerging adults., Author: Atkin, Annabelle L.; Jackson, Kelly F.; White, Rebecca M. B.; Tran, Alisia G. T. T.; Journal: Journal of Family Psychology, Volume: 36, Issue: 2 Pages: 179-190 Year: 2022 DOI: 10.1037/fam0000918 ISSN: 1939-1293, 0893-3200 This qualitative interview study investigated the types of parental racial-ethnic socialization messages received by Multiracial American youth over the course of their development. The Multiracial population in America is the largest demographic group among individuals under the age of 18 (Saulny, 2011), but there is a dearth of research about the development of this rapidly growing population. Multiracial youth are members of multiple racial-ethnic groups. Thus, racial-ethnic socialization is particularly complex for Multiracial families because parents typically have different racial backgrounds and experiences compared to their children. Interviews were conducted with 20 Multiracial emerging adult college students (Mage = 20.55; 10 male, 10 female) of diverse racial backgrounds to identify the types of parental racial-ethnic socialization messages they received growing up. Using thematic analysis (Braun & Clarke, 2006), nine themes of racial-ethnic socialization content emerged: Cultural socialization, racial identity socialization, preparation for bias socialization, colorblind socialization, race-conscious socialization, diversity appreciation socialization, negative socialization, exposure to diversity socialization, and silent socialization. This research advances the literature by (a) identifying domains of racial-ethnic socialization messages for Multiracial American families, (b) examining a diverse sample of male and female Multiracial youth, (c) differentiating monoracial versus Multiracial socialization messages, and (d) distinguishing the unique connotations of egalitarian socialization messages (e.g., colorblind, raceconscious, diversity appreciation). The ﬁndings have important implications for understanding the development of Multiracial American individuals and families. Keywords: #Multiracial #Biracial #Qualitative It was not until 1967 that interracial marriages became legal across the US with the Loving v. Virginia case. The Multiracial population in America is the largest demographic group among individuals under the age of 18. There is a dearth of research about the development of this rapidly growing population. There is a lack of research that examines how Multiracial American families navifate racial issues and prepare their children for living in a society dominated by monocentrism, which assumes every individual is associated with only one racial group and pathologizes and excludes those who do not fit this norm. More research is needed that examines racial-ethnic socialization or the transmission of messages from caregivers to children about the meaning of their racial-ethnic group membership, in Multiracial families. Socialization from caregivers plays an important role in reducing the negative effects of racial inequities by helping children of color understand race, develop a strong sense of identity, and build resilience to racial conflict.
Critical Multiracial Theory (MultiCrit)
Ecological Model of Biethnic Identity Formation Theorizes how race-related factors work together to inform development. This model posits that the messages that caregivers give about their child's racial-ethnic heritage and culture might shape how the Multiracial child understands their racial-ethnic identity and prepare them for responding to racial discrimination. Little is know about how this process of racial-ethnic socialization plays out in Multiracial families. Parents may not know how to provide useful messages or may even convey discriminatory messages to their child. The model posits that social climate affects Multiracial youths' experiences of racial-ethnic socialization and identity development. Previous qualitative studies examining racial-ethnic socialization in Multiracial families have found that monoracial parents typically do not talk explicitly about race and ethnicity with children, utilizing colorblind messages that deemphasize the significance of structural racism instead. One recent study with transracially adopted Korean American adults raising Multiracial children found that parents did engage in socialization promoting monoracial identities (i.e., Asian American or White), but did not specifically promote Multiracial identity. MultiCrit highlights that on top of racism and colorism, Multiracial youth experience monoracism, or discrimination based on one's Multiracial status. Multiracial youth report being exoticized, tokenized, objectified, placed into monoracial boxes, rejected, and forced to pick a monoracial identity to appease monoracial peers. Seven domains of racial-ethnic socialization experienced by Multiracial American youth: Cultural Socialization Encompasses messages about cultural traditions and values and exposure to people, foods, and other aspects associated with one's racial-ethnic heritage. Racial Identity Socialization Involves messages about how the child belongs to and should be proud of their membership in various racial-ethnic groups, as well as labels they can use to racially identify themselves. Preparation for Bias Messages Teaches children about racial stereotypes, prejudice, and discrimination they may face based on their race and create space for dialog about experiences of racism within the family. Egalitarian Socialization Prioritizes messages about everyone being the same Negative Socialization Encompasses implicitly or explicitly conveyed prejudicial Exposure to Diversity Messages Exposure to diversity through schools and communities was another way parents influenced their children's racial-ethnic socialization. No Racial-Ethnic Socialization Some parents were silent on the topic of race or actively avoided or ignored the topic. Nine themes representing the content of racial-ethnic socialization messages emerged from the analysis of the interviews Racial Identity Socialization Preparation for Bias Socialization Colorblind Socialization Diversity Appreciation Socialization Race-Conscious Socialization Exposure to Diversity Socialization Negative Socialization Silent Socialization Involves exposure to the customs and traditions of youths' heritage cultures. Participants reported learning about and experiencing many different cultural aspects from their parents including language, food, clothing, traditional dance, media, and holidays, which helped them feel more connected to their cultures. Participants also learned about their culture through stories about their family history and the history of the parent's origin country, visiting their parent's country of origin, and participating in cultural events such as local festivals or community parties with family friends from a specific ethnic background. Food was the most prominent connection Multiracial youth had to their culture. Food was a cultural aspect that crossed over from one parent to the other, in that moms would learn from their mother-in-law how to cook dishes specific to their husband's culture. Food was an important way that family celebrated their multiple cultures. Language Socialization There were parents who knew their partners, making it another aspect of shared family culture for Multiracial families. Racial identity socialization involved messages from parents to Multiracial youth explaining their racial-ethnic background(s) and sometimes also telling them which labels they could or should use to identify with their racial background. Some racial identity socialization messages acknowledged the Multiracial nature of youths' identities, while others encouraged identification with only one racial-ethnic group. Certain messages from parents emphasized the monoracial aspects of youths' identity. In certain situations, parents also encouraged youth to identify with the racial background that would be most advantageous to them in achieving a goal. Youth were taught to focus on only one of their heritages if it would help them in applying to jobs or schools. There were also messages from parents that highlighted youths' multiple heritages or Multiracial identity. Participants reported that their parents taught them that they were members of all of their groups, though the term 'Multiracial' was rarely ever mentioned. "You are both things, you are biracial... Definitely identify as such." Even second-generation Multiracial youth were reminded to acknowledge all of their backgrounds. Preparation for bias socialization involved both making Multiracial youth aware of racial biases that others might have due to their racial-ethnic heritage and teaching them how to respond to or cope with experiences of others racially discriminating against them. Preparation for bias also occurred through parents sharing the experiences they had with discrimination played. Moreover, youth learned from their parents by witnessing them experiencing discrimination and seeing how they responded. Messages that prepared youth for bias in ways that were applicable to discrimination targeted at both their monoracial and Multiracial groups were labelled General Preparation for Bias Messages. One way parents suggested that Multiracial youth handle racial bias was by ignoring people who discriminated against them and letting things go.

headers.heading: A qualitative examination of familial racial-ethnic socialization experiences among multiracial American emerging adults.
Review of Racial-Ethnic Socialization Literature with Multiracial Families

adolescent-and-emerging-adulthood/5.-rac.description:
Bibliography:
Type: Journal Article
Title: Identity Formation in Adolescence: The Dynamic of Forming and Consolidating Identity Commitments, Author: Crocetti, Elisabetta; Journal: Child Development Perspectives, Volume: 11,
Issue: 2
Pages: 145-150
Year: 2017 DOI: 10.1111/cdep.12226
ISSN: 1750-8592, 1750-8606
The biological, cognitive, and social changes that occur in adolescence stimulate young people to think about themselves, reﬂect on the kind of people they want to become, and ﬁnd their place in society. Traditionally, these changes have been explained by Erikson’s theory and Marcia’s identity status model, but process-oriented models of identity provide new insights. In particular, dual-cycle models, such as the three-factor identity model, focus on the dynamic process by which young people iteratively form and maintain their identity over time. This iterative process is captured by the interplay of commitment, in-depth exploration, and reconsideration of commitment, as well as by distinct identity statuses. Furthermore, the extent to which adolescents ﬁnd a stable identity is intertwined strongly with their psychosocial functioning and well-being.
Keywords: Need to Read

headers.heading: Identity Formation in Adolescence: The Dynamic of Forming and Consolidating Identity Commitments

adolescent-and-emerging-adulthood/5.-rac.description:
Bibliography:
Type: Journal Article
Title: Racial/ethnic socialization for White youth: What we know and future directions, Author: Loyd, Aerika Brittian; Gaither, Sarah E.; Journal: Journal of Applied Developmental Psychology, Volume: 59,
Pages: 54-64
Year: 2018 DOI: 10.1016/j.appdev.2018.05.004
ISSN: 01933973
Teaching and talking about race and ethnicity with children and adults is especially important in racially diverse societies. This process has been coined racial/ethnic socialization (RES). Despite the importance of RES, we still know very little about how this process unfolds in the lives of White youth. Thus, from a social, cognitive, and developmental perspective, the authors summarize ﬁndings from empirical research and theory on RES for White youth across stages of development—early childhood through young adulthood. Since RES is linked with cross-group attitudes (e.g., less bias, prejudice, stereotyping) and behaviors (e.g., inclusion), we highlight future directions for research and discuss applications for existing ﬁndings for an increasingly diverse society.
Keywords: Need to Read

headers.heading: Racial/ethnic socialization for White youth: What we know and future directions

adolescent-and-emerging-adulthood/5.-rac.description:
Bibliography:
Type: Journal Article
Title: “So, like, it’s all a mix of one”: Intersecting contexts of adolescents’ ethnic‐racial socialization, Author: Sladek, Michael R.; Umaña‐Taylor, Adriana J.; Hardesty, Jennifer L.; Aguilar, Gladys; Bates, David; Bayless, Sara Douglass; Gomez, Elisa; Hur, Connie K.; Ison, Ashley; Jones, Shandra; Luo, Hua; Satterthwaite‐Freiman, Megan; Vázquez, Michael A.; Journal: Child Development, Volume: 93,
Issue: 5
Pages: 1284-1303
Year: 2022 DOI: 10.1111/cdev.13756
ISSN: 0009-3920, 1467-8624
Cultural-­ecological theories posit that ethnic-r­ acial identity (ERI) development is shaped by transactions between contexts of ethnic-­racial socialization, yet research considering intersections among multiple contexts is limited. In this study, Black, Latino, White, and Asian American adolescents (N = 98; Mage = 16.26, SD = 1.09; 55.1% female identifying) participated in surveys and focus group discussions (2013–­2014) to share insights into ERI development in context. Using consensual qualitative research, results indicated: (a) family ethnic-­racial socialization intersects with community-­based, peer, media, and school socialization; (b) ethnic-­ racial socialization occurs outside family through intersections between peer, school, community-­based, and media settings; and (c) ethnic-r­ acial socialization is embedded within systems of racial oppression across contexts. Discussion includes implications for future research and interventions supporting youth ERI.
Keywords: Need to Read

headers.heading: “So, like, it’s all a mix of one”: Intersecting contexts of adolescents’ ethnic‐racial socialization

adolescent-and-emerging-adulthood/5.-rac.description:
Bibliography:
Type: Journal Article
Title: Ethnic–Racial Socialization in the Family: A Decade's Advance on Precursors and Outcomes, Author: Umaña‐Taylor, Adriana J.; Hill, Nancy E.; Journal: Journal of Marriage and Family, Volume: 82,
Issue: 1
Pages: 244-271
Year: 2020 DOI: 10.1111/jomf.12622
ISSN: 0022-2445, 1741-3737
Abstract
In the current decade, the U.S. population reached historically high levels of ethnic–racial diversity and reelected the nation's first Black–White biracial President. Simultaneously, scholars also documented significant ethnic–racial inequities in education, increased xenophobia, and a racial climate that revealed deep‐seated ethnic–racial tensions. Given this backdrop and acknowledging the significant role that families play in youths' abilities to navigate their social contexts, the current review focused on the literature on families' ethnic–racial socialization efforts with youth from the 2010 decade. Our review of 259 empirical articles revealed that there has been an exponential increase in research on family ethnic–racial socialization in this decade. Furthermore, although it is clear that family ethnic–racial socialization is a robust predictor of youths' adjustment, the associations between socialization and adjustment must be considered with attention to specific socialization strategies, the confluence of strategies used, and the unique contexts within which families' lives are embedded.
Keywords: Need to Read

headers.heading: Ethnic–Racial Socialization in the Family: A Decade's Advance on Precursors and Outcomes

adolescent-and-emerging-adulthood/final-.title: Project Outline
adolescent-and-emerging-adulthood/final-.description: The capacity to maintain one's own identity (thoughts, values, and beliefs) while remaining emotionally connected to others. Murray Bowen introduced this concept to explain how individuals manage anxiety and stress by separating thinking from emotional reactivity. Refers to the intensity and immediacy of emotional responses. Highly reactive individuals may be overwhelmed by stress, clouding rational thinking. Example. An individual who becomes instantly upset over minor criticism, indicating difficulty in self-regulating. A strategy to manage anxiety by distancing oneself from emotionally charged relationships. Example. An adult who avoids family reunions to escape unresolved conflicts. Although cutoff can reduce immediate distress, it prevents long-term resolution and growth. Describe overly close, undifferentiated relationships where boundaries are blurred. Example. A person who mirrors a parent's moods and opinions to the point of losing their own identity. The ability to assert one's own beliefs and maintain a distinct sense of self even under pressure from family members. Clinical implication Strengthening the I-position is a key therapeutic goal, helping clients balance intimacy with independence. Lower differentiation is associated with chronic anxiety, dependency, and interpersonal difficulties. Studies on dyadic adjustment (e.g., Lampisa's work) show that higher differentiation correlates with more satisfying intimate relationships. A triangle is formed when a two-person (dyadic) relationship becomes unstable due to anxiety, prompting the includsion of a third party to diffuse tension. Triangles are considered the smallest stable emotional unit in a family. They serve to distribute and manage anxiety but can also perpetuate problematic dynamics.

adolescent-and-emerging-adulthood/1..htm.description: Developmental Systems Perspective Adolescent development is best understood as a dynamic interplay between the individual and their changing context. Long-term impact of adolescence While acknowledging the influence of early childhood experiences, both sources highlight the unique and lasting impact of adolescent experiences on adult outcomes. Authors criticize traditional theories that separate individual and context, arguing that they fail to capture the relational nature of development. Developmental Systems Model This model considers the dynamic interplay of multiple levels of organization, from biological to cultural. This model emphasizes Change and Relative Plasticity Individuals and contexts are constantly changing, and this plasticity allows for potential interventions to promote positive development Relationism and Integration Variables from different levels of organization are interconnected and influence each other. Historical Embeddedness and Temporality Development is embedded within historical time, leading to both continuity and discontinuity within and between individuals. Limits of Generalizability, Diversity, and Individual Differences The dynamic nature of development limits generalizability and highlights the importance of considering individual and contextual diversity. Implications for Research and Application This model calls for multilevel, longitudinal research to understand individual-context relations and design intervention that alter those relations in positive directions. 'Shot Out of a Cannon' models emphasize early childhood experiences determining life trajectory. 'Contact Sport' models acknowledge the continuous interaction between individual and context throughout life. Research shows that interventions targeting early childhood influence long-term outcomes by impacting specific adolescent factors like substance use onset, teen births, and educational attainment. The authors advocate for longitudinal studies explicitly designed to test the unique contribution of adolescence to long-term outcomes. The authors hypothesize that childhood and adolescence likely have both cumulative and domain-specific effects on adult outcomes. Both sources agree that adolescence is a critical developmental period with lasting impacts on adult outcomes. They advocate for a developmental systems approach that recognizes the dynamic interplay between individual and context throughout the lifespan. Future research should prioritize longitudinal studies explicitly designed to pinpoint the specific characteristics and experiences during adolescence that contribute most significantly to diverse long-term outcomes. This knowledge will inform effective policies and interventions to maximize the positive potential of adolescence for individuals and society as a whole.

adolescent-and-emerging-adulthood/1..htm.author: Millie

adolescent-and-emerging-adulthood/7.-fam.title: 7. Family Influences
adolescent-and-emerging-adulthood/7.-fam.description:
I. OverviewThis document summarizes findings from five research articles focusing on various aspects of adolescent development, with an emphasis on the role of family dynamics, cultural factors, and individual experiences in shaping adolescent well-being. The themes covered include:
The impact of adolescent secrecy and disclosure on adjustment.
Parental strategies for gaining knowledge about their adolescents' lives and the influence of these strategies on adolescent outcomes.
The interplay of cultural and general stressors on Latinx adolescents' mental health and the protective role of familismo.
The importance of family acceptance for the mental and physical health of LGBT adolescents.
II. Key Themes and FindingsA. Secrecy vs. Disclosure in Adolescent-Parent Relationships (Frijns et al., 2010)
Core Argument: The traditional measure of adolescent disclosure to parents conflates two distinct constructs: disclosure (what adolescents freely share) and secrecy (what adolescents actively conceal). Secrecy has a stronger impact on adolescent adjustment than previously recognized.
Key Findings:Factor analysis confirmed that disclosure and secrecy are separate constructs.
"Only secrecy was a longitudinal predictor of adolescent internalizing (i.e., depression)..."
Secrecy and delinquency were reciprocally related over time.
Increased secrecy is linked to "stress-related psychological problems, prevent full processing of the secret information, and cause mental rumination and obsessive preoccupation with the secret."
Implications: Researchers should distinguish between disclosure and secrecy when studying adolescent-parent relationships. Interventions should address the underlying reasons for adolescent secrecy.
B. Parental Knowledge and Strategies (Liu et al., 2020)
Core Argument: Parental knowledge of adolescent activities is influenced by both parent-driven strategies (e.g., solicitation, control, warmth) and child-driven strategies (e.g., disclosure).
Key Findings:Children's disclosure is the strongest predictor of parental knowledge compared to parental solicitation, behavioral control, and psychological control. The meta-analysis showed a significant correlation between children's disclosure and parental knowledge (ρ = 0.523, p < 0.001).
Psychological control is negatively associated with parental knowledge.
Parental warmth and behavioral control indirectly contribute to parental knowledge by promoting children's disclosure. "Parental warmth seems to provide the basis for high-quality children's disclosure."
Cultural differences exist: The association between behavioral control and parental knowledge was stronger in Eastern cultures compared to Western cultures.
Implications: Parents should focus on fostering warm, supportive relationships with their children to encourage open communication and voluntary disclosure.
C. Stress and Familismo in Latinx Adolescents (Montoro & Ceballo, 2021)
Core Argument: Both cultural and general stressors impact Latinx adolescents' psychological well-being, but familismo (a strong emphasis on family unity, support, and obligation) can serve as a protective factor.
Key Findings:Family-based cultural stressors were associated with increased depressive symptoms whereas familismo was associated with fewer depressive symptoms
Greater material need was associated with increased depressive symptoms and a less positive future orientation.
"Familismo protected adolescents from depressive symptoms linked to material hardship."
Racial discrimination is positively associated with anxiety
Implications: Interventions should leverage the strength of familismo to help Latinx adolescents cope with stress and promote positive mental health outcomes.
D. Family Acceptance and LGBT Adolescent Health (Ryan et al., 2010)
Core Argument: Family acceptance is a critical protective factor for LGBT adolescents, significantly impacting their mental and physical health in young adulthood.
Key Findings:"Family acceptance predicts greater self-esteem, social support, and general health status; it also protects against depression, substance abuse, and suicidal ideation and behaviors."
LGBT adolescents with low family acceptance were more than three times as likely to report suicidal ideation and suicide attempts compared to those with high family acceptance.
Latino, immigrant, religious, and low-socioeconomic status families appear to be less accepting, on average, of LGBT adolescents
Implications: Promote interventions that educate and support families in accepting their LGBT children to reduce health disparities and improve well-being.
III. Quotes
Frijns et al. (2010): "Only secrecy was a longitudinal predictor of adolescent internalizing (i.e., depression)..."
Liu et al. (2020): "Parental warmth seems to provide the basis for high-quality children's disclosure."
Montoro & Ceballo (2021): "Familismo protected adolescents from depressive symptoms linked to material hardship."
Ryan et al. (2010): "Family acceptance predicts greater self-esteem, social support, and general health status; it also protects against depression, substance abuse, and suicidal ideation and behaviors."
IV. Overall ImplicationsThese studies collectively highlight the crucial role of family relationships in adolescent development. They emphasize the importance of open communication, parental warmth and support, cultural understanding, and acceptance in promoting adolescent well-being. The findings suggest that interventions should focus on strengthening family bonds, addressing both cultural and economic stressors, and promoting positive family dynamics to support healthy adolescent development.

adolescent-and-emerging-adulthood/untitl.description: Adolescent7You aced a difficult exam, but you studied with a friend you parents don't approve of.You went to a party, and there was underage drinking. You did not participate, but you are unsure how your parents will react.You've started dating someone from a different cultural background, and you are unsure how your parents will react.You are feeling insecure about your appearance and have been considering extreme dieting.You are being bullied at school, but you don't want your parents to worry.You are questioning the religious beliefs that your parents taught you and exploring other spiritual paths.You have developed strong political views that differ significantly from your parents', and you are concerned about causing conflict.+ Add a cardParent4This parents values emotional connection and understanding. They prioritize open communication and want their child to feel safe sharing anything with them.(Controlling & Intrusive) This parent emphasizes rules and monitoring. They believe it is their responsibility to know everything about their child's life to keep them safe. This parent's psychological control may inhibit the child's disclosure for fear of a harmful reaction.(Anxious & Overprotective) This parents focused on safety and potential risks. They tend to worry excessively and may overreact to perceived threats.(Disengaged & Distant) This parent shows little interest in the adolescent's life. They may be preoccupied with their own problems or struggle to connect emotionally with their child.+ Add a cardExternal Influence5(Peer Pressure) Your friends encourage you to keep this a secret, saying your parents wouldn't understand and would just make things worse.(Cultural Norms) In your culture, this topic is considered taboo to discuss with parents, as it's seen as disrespectful or inappropriate.(Past Experiences) Last time you shared something similar, your parent overreacted, leading to a huge argument and a loss of trust.(Media Influence) A TV show you watched portrayed parents as being completely out of touch with teenagers' lives, making you think your parent might not understand.(Discrimination) An adolescent may not share a story of discrimination with their parents, fearing negative parental reactions.+ Add a card

family-development-(2200)/announcements..title: Announcements
family-development-(2200)/announcements..description:
Ohio History Connection Mozarts The oval Scioto deer Varsity club The shoe North market Kelton house In this week's spotlight for attractions, we have Ohio History Connection (https://www.ohiohistory.org/Links to an external site.)! The Ohio History Connection, formerly the Ohio Historical Society, is a statewide history organization with the mission to spark discovery of Ohio’s stories. As a nonprofit organization chartered in 1885, the Ohio History Connection carries out history services for Ohio and its citizens focused on preserving and sharing the state’s history. This includes housing the State Historic Preservation Office, the official state archives and the Community Engagement Department and managing more than 50 sites and museums across Ohio. I participated in their event on site. They hosted a bunch of reenactors there to reenact the 1950s! For our restaurant, this week I chose Mozart's (https://mozartscafe.com/Links to an external site.)! Mozart's has been a Clintonville destination for over 20 years. Mozart’s brings Europe to Columbus through breakfast, lunch, dinner, and an incredible variety of decadent European pastries. This "taste of Austria" is accompanied by live piano music and jazz on select nights. Make sure you also check out the beautifully restored building, which was built in the 1920s.Columbus lore... Columbus was first laid out in 1812 and incorporated in 1816. Columbus was not the original capital, but the state legislature chose to move the state government there after short periods in both Chillicothe and Zanesville. Columbus was chosen as the site for the new capital because of its central location within the state and access to transportation routes (primarily rivers) at that time. The legislature chose it as Ohio's capital over a number of other competitors, including Franklinton, Dublin, Worthington, and Delaware. Prior to the state legislature's decision in 1812, Columbus did not exist. The city was designed from the first as the state's capital, preparing itself for its role in Ohio's political, economic, and social life.During the twentieth century, Columbus continued to grow and prosper. Due to lighted arches that spanned over the city's major north-south thoroughfare, High Street, Columbus earned the reputation of being the most "brilliantly illuminated city in the country." Most of these arches disappeared by mid century, but in 2002, the city began to construct new ones to celebrate Columbus' past. If you would like to add any suggestions, please feel free to comment below!I hope this weather clears up and we get some sunny fall days. In this week's restaurant, I chose Belle's Bread. Tucked away in the Japanese marketplace located on Kenny Centre Mall, Belle’s BreadLinks to an external site. is a family-owned and -operated, French-inspired Japanese bakery. Takashi Takenaka opened the business after immigrating from Japan in 1972, and he pays homage to childhood treats with his red bean roll, frank roll, and curry and boiled egg doughnuts. The bear-shaped strawberry cream bun is all over social media, but the best-kept secret is the Mont Blanc roll with its layers of delicate, airy sweet cream and chestnuts.

Describe the contemporary social scrip that characterizes romantic relationship formation for college students and young adults. Evaluate how relationship rituals such as texting, hooking up, online dating, datings apps are changing partner selection and intimate relationships. Critique marital attitudes over the past 150 years and their effect on mate selection. On this week's Columbus lore, I thought I would bring it a little closer to home and look into OSU's history. You know that beautiful building you most likely walk by regularly called University Hall? Well, do I have some interesting facts for you.This was the first classroom building opened in 1873! 
“Announcements-1.png” could not be found. “Announcements-2.png” could not be found.
On the first day of classes in September 1873, the students entered an unfinished University Hall. This first building on campus was a classroom building, library, administrative office building, and it had apartments for faculty and dormitory rooms for male students. (The students moved out when the first dormitory opened in 1874). It even housed the Geology Museum until Orton Hall opened in 1893. University Hall had a chapel as well, which was originally used for a daily religious service.
In the spring of 1968 concern about the building's structural integrity led to a study of its safety. It was determined to be unsafe, and on May 9, 1968, the Board of Trustees instructed the administrative officials of the University to move everything out of the building. University Hall was torn down in September 1971. Today’s University Hall occupies almost exactly the same spot as the original University Hall (it is slightly east). When the original University Hall was torn down, there was quite a bit of discussion over which architectural style the new building should have. Eventually, University officials decided to make the new University Hall look the same as the original building on the outside. Although less ornamental, and smaller, today’s University Hall is still a landmark on campus. It was completed in 1976. (https://library.osu.edu/site/buckeyestroll/university-hall/Links to an external site.)For a random Columbus restaurant, I wanted something close to campus. I chose Emmett's Cafe! This bakery/cafe is located in the Old North. Inspired by Australian coffee culture, Emmett’s is the top pick for morning hangouts with a flat white or cold brew. This laid-back spot recently opened a second, much larger and brighter location at the Open Air building, a renovated school building in Old North. Open until 2pm during the work week, the cafe offers wifi and plenty of space to spread out with a few coworkers. Food options go far beyond pastries, with options like overnight oats, filling breakfast sandwiches, grain bowls, wraps, and even a wagyu burger. A random attraction, one that is certainly not everyone's taste, but I thought I would share nonetheless, Wagner-Hagans Auto Museum! This is a small museum without regular staff, so you do need to call and schedule an appointment to tour the museum.I am certainly not one to be personal, but I thought it was only appropriate to share. Originally, there was no formal plan for an Oval. The space in front of University Hall was intended to be a large rectangle, in the tradition of an English manor.By 1900, however, the Oval began to form as buildings cropped up around the open space. In 1905 there were no sidewalks and students joked of people disappearing into the mud. The mud paths were studied and eventually their locations influenced where sidewalks were placed.The Oval also contains several memorials. The most well-known is perhaps “The Five Brothers,” which is composed of five elm trees planted as a class gift. The originals were planted in 1891 and succumbed to Dutch Elm Disease, the last in 1971; the replacements were planted in 1987. Other memorials include the flagpole in front of Bricker Hall, dedicated in 1917 to graduates killed in WWI, and a sundial, a gift from the class of 1905, which now stands in Sphinx Plaza.The Oval has been home to commencements, rallies, student demonstrations, cavalry drills, contests, and even a musical chairs contest for charity.
Riveting Restaurants: Anthony Thomas Candy Company.!
Anthony Zanetos immigrated to the United States from Greece in 1907. His first job was as an apprentice candy maker in a local candy shop in Columbus, Ohio. It was in 1916, when Anthony experienced the urge to go into business for himself. This decision molded the lives of four generations. In 1932, Anthony opened the Co-op Dairy at the corner of Chicago Avenue and Broad Street in Franklinton. It was Anthony’s dream for a father and son business. In 1945 Anthony’s son Tom, returned home from service following W.W.II. Together they started Anthony’s Confectionary where the Co-op Dairy used to be. Following the war, sugar was rationed and Veterans that were in the candy business could get a 30,000-pound annual allotment of sugar, which made Tom a valuable asset and an instant partner with his father. Realizing the quality of the candy was creating a demand, Tom and his father decided to make it a full time trade, and using their first names they formed the Anthony-Thomas Candy Company in 1952.Astounding Activities: The Scioto Deer “Announcements-8.png” could not be found.You may have probably seen at least one of the three bronze deer sculptures located throughout Columbus, but do you know why they’re actually there? It’s okay, neither did I. These friendly, relaxed-looking deer were added to the Scioto Mile as part of the big rehabilitation project in 2014 that turned the area into the incredible multi-use park and trail space it is now.There are a total of three deer along the Scioto River admiring the river, and they were put in during the renovation. Two of these funky art pieces are behind COSI and the other is on the Rich Street Bridge watching over our beloved city. So don’t worry everyone, the deer are protecting us. I hope you all have a great week. I should be on tomorrow for our office hours if you may need anything (My office hours are Tuesdays from 1p-2p). On this week's Columbus lore, we are back on campus with my personal favorite: Mirror Lake
It is very fitting to choose this wonderful place as our topic for Columbus Lore. The first contact with the lake was not with a person, as its history might suggest, but a horiculture wagon! Students rolled the wagon into the lake as a Halloween prank in 1895. The lake has a history of dunking freshman and tug-of-war across the lake. The Lantern depicted a freshman in the middle of the lake, dubbed the 'Freshman Bathtub.' In the 1920s, the tradition of dunking freshmen into the lake had been given approval from the student council and the university president. The rules: Freshmen must wear a specific cap at all times and not step food on the Long Walk, the brick path across the Oval leading up to Thompson library. Only assigned enforcers of the Bucket and Dipper club were allowed to toss freshmen into the lake. The last the lake would see of any tug-of-war across the lake was around the 1950s. It was stated the 3 minutes it took for one side to take over the other felt like 3 hours for people in attendance! In 1964, an engaged couple 'quarreled' at the lake; the man took back the engagement ring and threw it in the lake, and the woman went searching for it in a bikini. She was initially arrested but the executive dean finally allowed her to resume the search in different attire. She found the ring!“Announcements-9.png” could not be found.
Riveting Restaurants: Thurn's Specialty MeatsOn easter weekend in 1886, Alois 'Grospop' Thurn opened up a stall at the old Central Market and began selling old world style, processed items. He immigrated to Columbus from Germany a few years before and had begun working at a processing plant. He used the scraps to make meals for his family, and then his neighbors. In 1958, with the new interstate encroaching, his son, Alois, along with his grandsons, Robert, Paul and Leo, began construction on a new plant and storeroom.  This facility is still in use today.  In 1965, the Thurn brothers moved out the Central Market, 2 years before its demise.  Since that time, 530 Greenlawn Avenue is the only place to buy Thurn’s products.Astounding Activities: “Announcements-10.png” could not be found.

Mr. Ted has been coming to campus with me, so if you ever see us walking by don't be afraid to say hi!Have a fantastic week!Warmest regards,Millie Lynn AshHi Buckeyes!Though we are not covering anything this week, I wanted to send an announcement out to all of you regarding the event that will take place for each of you tomorrow. Thanksgiving is a time to gather with our families, eat some nice hearty food, and take a wondrous carb nap afterwards! For some, you may not celebrate or do anything at all. My home is open to each and every one of you if you do not have anyone to celebrate the holidays with. You have become a part of my family over this semester, even if I still have yet to actually meet you in person. As we have learned, family is a broad spectrum that includes a variety of circumstances, contexts, and people. Our family includes those we love, those we don't, those who would answer their phone in the middle of the night, those we turn to in times of need, those we learn from, and so many more. Whatever role your family plays in your life, please know you will be forever in mine. I will always be here to support you on your journey to wherever you are going. To change tune a bit, do you really know the origins of Thanksgiving? Thanksgiving is known for its yummy food and terrible traffic, but did you know the first European Thanksgiving in the United States was celebrated in 1564? This tradition, though centuries old, was not the first. The credit for that event goes to Native Americans.From contemporaneous records, we know that the Pilgrims and Native Americans had turkey and other game birds, as well as sea foods, venison, Indian corn, beans, berries, and nuts. They drank mostly beer, wine, and whiskies - all safer than the local water. Thanksgiving as a holiday originates from the Native American philosophy of giving without expecting anything in return. In the first celebration of this holiday, the Wampanoag tribe provided not only the food for the feast but also the teachings of agriculture and hunting (corn, beans, wild rice, and turkey are some specific examples of foods introduced by Native Americans).Though you may have known about the information above, did you know that the fourth Thursday in November (Thanksgiving) is recognized as the National Day of Mourning for Native Americans and their families.  For many Native Americans, Thanksgiving is a day of mourning and protest since it commemorates the arrival of settlers in North America and the centuries of oppression and genocide that followed. While some Native Americans have chosen to reject the Thanksgiving holiday entirely, many embrace the positive messages of the day and choose to put aside thoughts about its complex history. This is because the idea of giving thanks is central to Native heritage and culture. In this way, Thanksgiving is simply a chance to appreciate the good things in life, like family, community, and the riches of the land. Long before settlers arrived, Native tribes celebrated the autumn harvest and the gift of Mother Earth's abundance. Native American spirituality, traditionally and today, emphasizes gratitude for creation, care for the environment, and recognition of the human need for communion with nature and others. Now, regardless of the day's ambiguous origin, many Native Americans will gather with friends and family and use the day to eat good food (many of the classic Thanksgiving dishes are inspired by indigenous foods) and give thanks. I hope you learned something from above, and remember to actually rest over break. I know how easy it is to just work through it, as I probably will. Do as I say, not as I do! Take care of yourselves, and drive safe. Tonight is the heaviest drinking night of the year, and I passed many accidents on my way today. Your life and safety matter more than those extra couple minutes you save. Whether you celebrate or don't, be kind, grateful, and gentle with yourself and others this break. Don't add to the population, don't subtract from the population, and don't get sent to prison. I can't becoming an auntie just yet!We are almost finished, I can't believe how quickly the time has flown by. It has been an absolute pleasure getting to know each and every one of you over the last several months. Remember, you always have a home with me. Warmest regards,Millie Lynn AshHappy Tuesday everyone!Though this announcement will be reaching you a day later than usual, I still wanted to check in on everyone. Descriptive statistics describe the state of the data. It summarizes and describes the characteristics of a data set whereas inferential statistics infer information about the sample participants based on their data. Inferential statistics uses data from a sample to make predictions or draw conclusions about a larger population. The results allow us to analyze the sample and infer predictions about the larger population. The General Linear Model (GLM) Assumes the residuals (variation of variables) will be 'normally distributed' Betas are regression weights that are optimally estimated based on their contribution of each variable to reasonable predictions of Y. Absolute value of b depends on the metric scale of the x variable that they modify
The Generalized Linear Model (GLzM) Extension of GLM Outcome variable follows different distributions than the 'normal distribution' (i.e., probability distributions, binomial distributions, gamma distributions, etc.) Binary/dichotomous, count data, etc. Outcome variable is traditionally related to the linear model through link functions. Categories that are distinct and which do not have numerical value Examples School Eye color Marital status Numerical values that only signify ranking. Examples Risk level Likert-scale questions Numerical data that has equibalent ranges between values but no meaningful zero. Examples SAT scores Percentile rankings Temperature in Fahrenheit or Celsius Same as interval, but with a meaningful zero. Data can be ranked, intervals are consistent. Examples Height Age Weight Temperature in Kelvin

glm-2/hw/hw-2.html.title: HW 2
glm-2/hw/hw-2.html.description:
The change in the dependent (outcome) variable for a one unit change in the independent (predictor) variable, while holding all other variables constant. Expressed in the original units of the dependent (outcome) and independent (predictor) variables. The values obtained after standardizing all variables (both dependent and independent variables) to have a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1. This allows for the newly calculated variables to represent the change in the dependent variable (in standard deviations) for one-standard deviation change in the value of the independent variable. Measures the relationship between two variables without controlling for any other variable(s) using simple correlation. We would use this when we want to understand the simple bivariate relationship between two variables. We would likely use the Pearson Correlation Coefficient R for this type of analysis. Measures the correlation between x and y while controlling for x2 (on both x and y). We would likely use this when we want to understand the direct relationship between two variables, independent of influence of other variables. Measures the relationship between two variables while controlling for the effect of one or more variables on only one of the two variables. Correlation between x and y while controlling for x2 (on x1 only) We would likely use this when we want to understand the exact contribution of an independent (predictor) variable to the dependent (outcome) variable, after taking into account the influence of other variables on the independent (predictor) variable. All predictors are added into the regression model at the same time. The model evaluates the contribution of each predictor to the outcome variable while controlling for all other predictors. R-squared is a static value that represents the variance explained in the outcome variable by the collective set of predictors. Continuous variable is added as it is
Nominal Variable must be dummy coded Variables with non-zero values should be ‘centered’ Predictors are entered into the model in a pre-specified order based theory-driven blocks. The model is built in blocks (steps) with each block adding one or more predictors. The change in the model’s R-squared is assessed at every step. A series of multiple-regression are performed, with each block being added to the next until all variables are included in the model. The final block of hierarchical multiple regression = simultaneous multiple regression. Very useful to look at the change in R-squared for each variable or blocks of variables Allow for testing hypotheses in the order of importance/priority of predictors. Squared semi-partial correlation provides the unique variance explained by a given variable. Predictors are added/removed from the model based on statistical criteria such as p-values or R-squared change rather than being theory-driven. Predictors are added/removed in data-driven blocks. Mathematically derives the highest R-squared value with the least number of predictors. CAUTION: NEVER USE THIS METHOD UNLESS STUDY IS ABSOLUTELY EXPLORATORY. Most predictive variables are added first Least predictive variables are removed first When you square the semi-partial correlation, it yields the proportion of the variance of y uniquely explained by x while controlling for all other predictors. Analyze > Regression > Linear Move dependent variable to Dependent. Move independent variable(s) to the Independent(s). - In Statistics, select Estimates (under Regression Coefficients), Model Fit, Descriptives, and Durbin-Watson (under Residuals, independence of errors). Click Continue. - In Plots, select Histograms and Normal Probability Plot (under Standardized Residual Plots). Move ZPRED under Y. Move ZRESID to X. Click Continue. - In Save, select Cook’s (under Distances). Click Continue. 3.     Click OK. The relationship between the independent (predictor) variables and the dependent (outcome) variables is linear. How to Check Use Scatterplots to visualize relationships. Click Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Scatter/Dot. Click Simple Scatter. Click Define. Move your dependent variable (outcome) to the Y-Axis. Move your independent variable (predictor) to the X-Axis. If the scatterplot is approximately linear, the assumption is met. If not linear, apply transformation. Observations are independent of each other (no autocorrelation, where observations are NOT independent) How to Check Use the Durbin-Watson test by clicking the option under Linear Regression: Statistics. If the Durbin-Watson test falls within the range of 1.5 – 2.5, the assumption is met.
If data is autocorrelated, use alternative models such as the generalized least squares (GLS) model. The residuals (errors) have constant variance across all levels of independent variable(s). How to Check Plot residuals vs. predicted values and look for a random scatter. In SPSS, request Linear Regression Plots. Move Y > ZPRED. Move X > ZRESID. If the scatterplots shows no overall pattern, the assumption is met. If assumption is violated, you can transform the dependent variable, use standard errors, or apply weighted least squares (WLS). The residuals (errors) are normally distributed. How to Check (For None or One Grouping Variable) Click Analyze > Descriptives > Explore Transfer the variable that needs to be tested for normality into the Dependent List box. Click on Statistics. Leave Descriptives selected. Click the Plots. Select Factor Levels Together under Boxplots. Select Stem-and-Leaf under Descriptive. Select Normality Plots with Tests. Click Continue. Click OK. Check Shapiro-Wilk Test of Normality, Normal P-P Plot, Histogram, and Skewness/Kurtosis. If the Sig. value of the Shapiro-Wilk Test is greater than p = .05, the data is normal. If it is below .05, the data significantly deviate from a normal distribution. If the points are generally along the diagonal of the Normal P-P Plot, the assumption is met. If the Histogram is approximately normal (distribution curve is bell-shaped), the assumption is met. If Skewness and Kurtosis are between +2 and -2, the assumption is met. How far a case is from some point of reference
Identifies the distance of cases from the mean (s) of predictor (s). Extreme cases in multivariate space are found via a cut-off point (critical value of Chi-Square Test) Measure the distance between an observed value and its predicted value that have all been converted to z-scores. Typically flag cases if they are 2 or 3 standard deviations away from the mean. How far a point deviates from the mean of that variable. Gauges the influence of the observed values over the predicted values. Ranges from zero to (N – 1) / N Average value is (k + 1) / N No greater than 2 (k + 1) / N or 3 (k + 1) / N The degree to which a variable can ‘pull’ the regression towards itself.
Cook's Distance Measures the overall influence of a case on the model Typically flagged if value is over 1 Factor loadings help determine which variable is associated with which latent factor. For example, several likert-scale questions on a questionnaire observing psychological outcomes may load highly on a ‘depressive/depression’ factor, showing they measure the same underlying construct. Higher values of factor loadings (e.g., > .4 or .5) indicate that a variable is a strong indicator of that factor. Lower values suggest the variable is less relevant to that factor. EFA can allow us to group variables with higher factor loadings on the same factor, reducing the complexity of our data.
3 The eigenvalue represents the amount of variance explained by each factor. If using the eigenvalue cutoff of 1, the cutoff is greater than 1 because the retained factors explain more variance. This can be seen on the Scree plot where there is a point where the slope of the curve changes, which is usually the cutoff for the number of factors we would retain. Factors to the left of the cutoff are considered meaningful. This is why there are only 3 out of the original 12 factors that were extracted from the analysis. The first three factors account for more of the variance in the model.

glm-2/hw/hw-3.html.description: A moderator is a variable that affects the strength or direction of the relationship between an independent variable (x) and a dependent variable (y). A mediator is a variable that explains the mechanisms or process through which an independent variable (x) affects a dependent variable (y). The purpose of the ‘seed’ option in a line of PROCESS syntax is to lock the random number generator. This ensures that the findings remain consistent across multiple runs of the analysis. Without specifying a ‘seed’ value, the random number generator would draw different values each time, leading to slightly different results. When a covariable absorbs variable from both the predictor and the error term, it can lead to: Sphericity is an assumption in repeated measures ANOVA that states the variance of the differences between all pairs of within-subject conditions (levels of the independent variable) should be equal. This means that if we have three time points (A, B, C), then the variance of (A – B) ≈ variance of (A – C) ≈ variance of (B – C). Sphericity is a special case of homogeneity of variance assumption and is specific to repeated measures designs. Potential Consequences of Violating Sphericity Inflated Type I Errors Rate (False Positives) Standard F-tests assume sphericity, so violating it increases the risk of finding a significant effect when none actually exists. The p-values become too small, leading to incorrect conclusions. Reduced Statistical Power (False Negative) If sphericity is violated and not corrected, the test might be too conservative, making it harder to detect real effects (Type II Error: Failing to detect a true effect). Distorted F-ratios The denominator degrees of freedom in the F-test get inflated which makes the ANOVA test statistics biased. This impacts the accuracy of hypothesis testing. Long-Format Data

glm-2/in-class-content/1.-glm-overview-p.description:
Logistic Regression When the outcome is dichotomous
Multinomial Logistic Regression When the outcome is categorical with more than two categories
Ordinal Logistic Regression When the outcome is ordinal Proportional odds or continuation ratio models
Poisson Regression and Negative Binomial Regression When the outcome is count data
Analytical Decision Tree for GLM Descriptive Statistics Descriptive statistics 'describe' the state of the data. More clear-cut, though with data transformation this can become complex. Inferential Statistics Inferential statistics 'infer' information about the participants based on their data. Can be descriptive but also predictive. 'Frequentist' Inferences Statistical inferences based on frequencies of probabilities.
Basis for Null Hypothesis statistical testing (NHST), statistical significance, Confidence Intervals, etc.
Nominal Variable or Nominal Variable Categories that are distinct and which do not have numerical value (e.g., school)
Ordinal Variables Numerical values that only signify ranking (e.g., risk level)
Interval Variable Numerical data that has equivalent ranges between values but no meaningful zero (e.g., SAT scores, percentile rankings, etc.)
Ratio Variable Same as interval, but with a meaningful zero (e.g., final exam scores) Linear = additive General model = linear in the parameters
Expected that the variation of variables will be 'normally distributed' (Normal Distribution) Beta's (b's) are regression weights that are optimally estimated based on their contribution of each variable to reasonable predictions of Y. Absolute value of b depends on the metric scale of the x variable that they modify.
Extension of the GLM The outcome variable follows different distributions I.e., probability distributions, binomial distributions, gamma distribution, poisson distributions, etc.
The outcome variable is non-linear (not continuous) Binary/dichotomous, count data, etc. The outcome variable is traditionally related to the linear model through link functions (such as transformations)

What are your research questions/hypotheses? Is your design correlational, experimental, or quasi-experimental? Is your study cross-sectional or longitudinal? Are assumptions of analyses being met a priori?
Regression Analysis Linearly related and normally distributed
Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) Independent observations, normally distributed, homogeneity (equal) variance across groups Familiarity with the dataset of your choosing How many cases? How many variables? Levels of measurement? Who are the participants? Is data identifiable? If not, is there a classification system in place? Any special considerations? Two methods of navigating SPSS Point and click Syntax A combination of both methods can produce a highly efficient (and less stressful) experience when using the software. Point and click menus are intuitive and clear for new users Syntax allows for a record of what has been done that can be easily reproduced and communicated with peers. Data editor See your data and variables directly Can carry out statistical functions Output viewer See the results of your analyses Syntax editor Enter text commands directly or save them from the data editor Analyze -> Descriptives -> Paste Formatting All statements end in a period (red text = bad; blue text = good) Comment to yourself by starting a line with * and end with a period . Not case-sensitive You can highlight any or all of a command to run it Structure Use the numeric lines to keep track of things Order the syntax logically and be sure to categorize! Using the Point and click method to create the desired syntax Descriptive statistics of variable(s) Analyze -> Descriptives -> Descriptives Using syntax File -> New -> Syntax Click on Window -> Designated Syntax Window Example Compute variable from existing variable Subtracting 1 from the value of the variables such as 'Whether mom graduated HS' with the original values being 1 'did not graduate' and 2 'graduated HS' to create dummy variable. COMPUTE hs_adj = mom_hs - 1 COMPUTE age_squared = mom_age**2 To square a value in syntax, include a double star (**) and 2 EXECUTE Highlight the computations and click RUN Commenting on Syntax Type the asterisks sign * computing new variable from an existing variable Even if the comments are highlighted, they will not be executed since they are just comments. To recode a variable (You can also do it manually from the variable view) RECODE mom_hs (2=1)(1=0) into new_mom_hs VARIABLE LABELS new_mom_hs "new mother's high school status" EXECUTE To create descriptive statistics DESCRIPTIVES VARIABLES mom_age kid_score /STATISTICS = MEAN STDDEV MIN MAX Highlight the computations and click RUN To create new group variable from existing variable (replacing variables with dummy coding) IF mom_age > 20 Mom_over = 1 IF mom_age <= 20 Mom_over = 0
Upper left quadrant is the 'Source' Upper right quadrant is the 'Environment/History' Lower left quadrant is the 'Console' Lower right quadrant are the 'Files/Plots/Packages/Help/etc.'
This just looks like a notebook where you write your code You can save this and share the file with your project mates You can make comments by beginning a line of code with '#' You can call it your R Script/Source You can create a new script by clicking the green '+' symbol on the top left corner and selecting 'R Script' To run a particular line of code, click 'run' or use 'Command + return' for Macbook and 'Control + Enter' for Windows
This is your 'Console' This is where the code you run from the source gets evaluated You can directly type your code here and get it evaluated, but the code will not be on your source/R Script
Shows all objects in your working space (e.g., your data, matrices, vector, functions, etc.) You can import data directly by using the 'Import Dataset' You can use the 'Broom' to clear all objects from the workspace.
You see your file directories You can view your plots You can see your 'Packages' and also install new packages You can read more about the function under 'Help' Make sure your Source file (R Script) and your dataset are saved (or located) in the same folder on your computer Set your working directory Steps: Click 'Session' -> Choose 'Set Working Directory' -> Select 'To Source File Location' First approach Click on 'Files' -> Select 'Import Dataset' -> Choose the data you want to import (e.g., Excel, SPSS data, STATA data, etc.) Second approach Click on 'Import Dataset' under 'ENVIRONMENT' -> Choose the data you want to import (e.g., Excel, SPSS data, STATA data, etc.) R comes with some functions which are free to use (e.g., mean (), sd ()) You do not need to install any package before using those functions However, to access a function written by others (other than the original 'authors' of R), you first have to install it as a 'package.' These packages often come with dataset(s), functions, examples, etc. Install a package using 'install.Packages ('name of the package)')' You need to install the package once and it will be on your computer permanently. After installing a package, you need to load it before having access to its functions, datasets, etc. Use 'library(name of package)' to load a package. There are many functions to explore your data View to have a quick view of your data Head to print out the first 6 rows Tail to print out the last 6 rows Summary to look at the summary of all your variables Psych::describe to check the descriptive statistics Use the dollar sign ($) to help select a specific variable E.g., mean(kids_score $age) will compute the mean for the variable age in the 'kids_score' dataset mean() to find the mean of a variable sd() to find the standard deviation var() to find variance sum() to find the totals Use '?' to learn more about a function nrow(data) to find the number of rows ncol(data) to find the number of columns colnames(data) to print the names of the columns (variables) str(data) to look at the structure of the variables
table() to print out the frequency in each group for a Nominal Variable min() and max() to find the minimum and maximum of a variable
